intro: Thlaspi alpestre var. californicum, commonly known as the California wallflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other flowering plants with small, four-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and is often found in alpine or coastal regions. Its foliage is usually basal, with leaves that are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs. The flowers are bright yellow and bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
